etymologies: late Middle English: from medieval Latin seto(n-), apparently from Latin seta ‘bristle’

definitions: a skein of cotton or other absorbent material passed below the skin and left with the ends protruding, to promote drainage of fluid or to act as a counterirritant.
shortDefinitions: skein of cotton or other absorbent material passed below skin and left with ends protruding, to promote drainage of fluid
